topic.title: multi client zeronet?
topic.body: is it possible to run 1 zeronet (client) node but then access it from multiple pc's in the private LAN?

topic.title: Zero Email ?
topic.body:
Hi!
I have been busy for last couple of months and in the meantime I did not manage to come to 0net. All is fine (generally). I had to update the version I am running but otherwise most of things worked except one puzzling thing - 0mail is 'downloading' 5000 messages... I am almost sure that I did not write 0email and I do not expect to have anything in the mailbox but nevertheless I have to download 5000 messages ... Is there a way to workaround this 'large' download?

Connection refused doduse najverovatnije znaci da datom portu nije dozvoljeno da se konektuje - znaci najverovatnije neki firewall, ili na samoj masini ili negde na mrezi (a cesto moze da se desi da neki drugi program zauzima port ili tvoj program startuje drugu kopiju servisa koji vec radi i zauzima port)

meni je ovo jedva radilo i bez tora dok nisam otvorio port na ruteru.
a nisi jedini koji se raspituje bice da ima bagova, sve ovo je sveze, bice tu svasta jos, pogledaj okolo ili baci porukicu na board.

1_12Ex3Mrd75wY2r5rB21jBcmgj9hxwUK1w2.body:
with this i am into exploring of resilient networks.
although it is not disputable that project like this may bring societal change and influence or be influenced by specific culture, i more see another important issue - survival. 
Try to imagine internet where dns system breaks down.... (not very likely to happen because dns is also distributed but it may under certain circumstances)
one of systems that will break along dns will be very likely this one too (or at least some parts of it).
freenet seem to be gone farthest in this sense, but still they had to make some provisions, otherwise it will break too (seems that they already experienced some of these issues in not so distant past)
we are nowhere near resilient network as yet.
its also curiosity, i believe we became bored with existing internet
there are some other things along these lines...

> [0nu](#comment_4_13zgtd1L3F7145JTZCJ2sdR5BdbdCV7v9M): Not involved in any projects (yet), but I'm pretty keen on cryptocurrencies and this whole 'decentralised internet' thing. OpenBazaar also sounds pretty rad. I only recently jumped on the ZeroNet bandwagon after looking something Freenet-related up on Wikipedia, so I'm sure there are other things I'm missing. Thus, if you or anyone else has recently come upon (or started working on) something similarly cool, feel free to mention it here. :)

check ethereum project

5_1QBLGLcgKfcpfLmiDYuDzUKVXFfmTAew55.body:
it would be nice to have links on nicknames:
in the way that nickname gets linked to the person's site (user defined default)
if person does not define site, a default profile page can be shown with options:
- send email
- see public key
- crypto-coins wallet(s)
- clone page code
... something else appropriate
... something that will be easy to edit and publish back

(
re: social network requests/board discussion - this would be like personal wall in fb, or page on myspace, or profile on linkedin, g+ etc etc
but it would be better than anything else
1. one can make whatever presentation - freedom
2. who knows design/programming can make profile templates - real work, showcase, market
3. one does not need to do anything / or very little and still have profile page - ideal for lazy
4. good educational value - how to make your profile page
5. one gets 'default' site key, no need to send this info in 'site lists', 'indexes'... everyone can make own index... publish list of friends, or not... put shop on, or not...
6. possibility to make crawlers - search for content (decentralized search)
7. knock yourself out with ideas :)
)

I rest my case ;)
your move (do you like it?, doable? etc)

we could have keyspace for web pages
perhaps another 'personal' keyspace
perhaps oher service-keyspace (for services and concepts not invented yet)

we could have keyspace for web pages
perhaps another 'personal' keyspace
perhaps oher service-keyspace (for services and concepts not invented yet)

14_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf.body:
> [gold](#comment_1_1PPqTMbH8Uwrk496grUVuBk57dSoeU9hig): Is Freenet active these days ?

Freenet is extremely inert system (imho) but net 'chatty', yes there is some activity and bots working but it is hard to tell what happens behind the scenes. but socially its far less dynamic than 0 net

> [melic](#comment_4_1BWsVpXFVzcpYwdgKhjCRuTx3xDTxyevKS): IMO 0-Net seems like it was designed more for usability while Freenet sacrifices some usability for more security and censorship resistance.

Its usable, its is just slow by concept (FN). I'd say this is something I'd use on weekend when I have time. 
0net is daily thing. Come check, eventually write, go...
I do not find it more secure. Like there is nothing secure about signing Microsoft EULA, so there is nothing safe about warning page that content may be harmful. Here you do not sign the content and view it, overthere you sign for content and again view it.... yes you are warned... (but each time?)

i have also tried to see if hugo (static site generator) will work (there was no reason why it shouldn't but to prove the point) - [hugo on zero](/126fBtopb2n7Pc42KhZyZyHhZKrecAdMdR)

> [oracle](#comment_105_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP): I know how to clone the blog but I want to add stuff to my blog without having to code anything, I want to change the background and add a header bar without having to go into the css and code it in myself and I want to add images to my blog without having to open html and edit it. I want my blog to have something like a CMS aka dashboard, where I can click on a button and search my local files to add images to the blog. Any idea how to add something like this https://imgur.com/Oq3kvSR to a zeronet website?

made something on [hugo on zero](/126fBtopb2n7Pc42KhZyZyHhZKrecAdMdR) - external images work, internal... ehm we shall see why not (wrapper? or just time to propagate)

> [oracle](#comment_106_1ED3Ho3kmzaKiECtyuqSjDpoE47rKuXeP): Do you know of any static site generators that has something like a dashboard or cms like in that picture?

well not as yet, most of cms do but for another principle of hosting
it will come eventually zeronet is still young and a bit specific, large content is not supported afaik, but there are ppl here who can shed more light
fixed issue on hugo site (I am the biggest bug ;) - wrong spelling

yes tinymce is good (for text) extremely configurable that's why it takes time to grasp
you still need a bit of backend cause it works in a browser

1_1EbkgVAJKgrTeYAmF3FSEJ8dRabpWH87it.body:
'When the f\*\*k can we get rid of the JS s\*\*t'?

I guess: (pesimistic) never..., (optimistic) in a while... (realistic) why the f..k we give a piece of s..t about that at all?

so lets examine 'fairy tales':

https://dzone.com/articles/cube-drone-comic-js-community-persistence-and-vers

Its in essence a fairy tale of ROI and money, which goes something like this:

"We had so much 'I' over several generations that we will never reach 'R', that is unless all expected 'R' is not going to be shown in 'M' because 'M' will cease to exist (or we bankrupt over expectation of 'R')."

and

"When we invented M, we thought it is going to have social function and help us exchange value of our contribution, only to realize it became a tool for ruling over our lives by declaring that M===success (and several other similar fairy tales), 
Yet we never ceased to believe in it (M), and continue to use it (M) even when it become a crypto soup (read: perceived freedom from establishment by introducing equivalent establishment or ERG, which is only fair until we find that holy grail called 'perpetual source of energy' - may god (or whatever improvable deistic supramundane intelligence) bless us  to find that :) )"

In the first part we can easily waste couple more of generations by declaring that we need to reach that magical 'R'. Or perhaps we can ignore the facts, and continue in CoffeScript, Dart, TypeScript and ES6 whatever s**t you believe it is 'solving the problem' of 'js'.

On the second part I have no comment, except that humanity may eventually get to the idea that happiness=success (and define happiness not in relation to magical 'M') and/or stop using improvable deistic supramundane intelligences to collect M for R and we all go kill ourselves in finding PSoE (so that we have endless supply of crypto keys). 

No offense, All the best from Zozon

2_1L4fuhUB75eAdVbDY9AJ4z2i2dwMho7MV8.body:
works with me. good. 
experience on my side is the same - i am puzzled with initial site propagation. After you have 2-3 peers publishing is breeze, but getting to 1st (other) peer sucks.
mantra: update, sign, publish.. update, sign, publish :)

it would be nice to have something to KICK underlying zeronet.py into peer propagation, noticed that it is very inert in contacting peers around. This is OK in normal (download other people) content. But when publishing, waiting minutes that it starts propagating is frustrating. Sometimes I do restart zero net to make it work earlier but also publishing from the command line works (at least it tries once to peer)

1_1PPqTMbH8Uwrk496grUVuBk57dSoeU9hig.body:
Shall I add pros/cons or express ideas what it can be done with the system like ZeroNet?
Or it is a time for another ICT fairy tale of mine :)
Many roads lead from question like this.

Thing to ponder #1: Trust.

Do you trust me if I publish a zero web site that I will not put JS that is harmful?

This is essential question for 0net. Currently there are no safeguards (not that there is much on normal net but google does publish black lists)

Currently 0net is small, people are coherent, but that will change in the time with more ppl/users. One can expect an attack (of the clones). In such case p2p do not help but aid malicious code - it can spread more easily.

We do not have mechanism how to protect individuals from such attacks, this is all currently based on mutual trust.

How to protect? This is open for discussion, there are different ideas so go ahead and speak your mind. 

BUT TRUST IS A PROBLEM (rather handling trust). You do want to discover this problem earlier where there are not a lot of us than later where there are thousands or milions or bilions of zeronauts.

p.s. this is 1 of 3 ideas what can (or shall) be done with 0net.

> [p2p](#comment_53_13Z7XxTa7JuFat3KzzMWu3onwM6biLuurJ): thanks for sharing. IMO, the worst thing of freenet is that it's based on java which many people hate.

I do not like java (actually hate it with passion), but some of my best friends are java developers, and its true there are good software written in java and x-platform and further more I use some of Java apps daily. With the same passion I hate .net :) I guess hating things for 20 years beats the point :)

In case of freenet it is much less about Java as it is about being unsure what goes thru your installation.
I guess tor is the same same but different, you relay pieces of info for other people. In case of tor this is fine, you do not get whole files, in cases of freenet I am not really sure that I may be hosting the content I do not want to host. Its concept to keep user isolated from the inner functionality is what is worrysome.

> [nippletwister](#comment_148_1PvAyLAB5H1JKbiFjx95ZJXrNJVyWxs5Hf): I didn't understand about the pandora box). What's new there?

as far as I can see this is old subject, picked up once and then forgotten. But then when I brought it with me today it spurred a lot of inspirational hacking (among html-ers) on how much can be done in the url line with and without JS. Fun time - hackatoon. Like opening a can of worms or pandora box. Ppl are killing problems with overly complex code where in some cases local storage and built in browser functionality can perfectly do the job. Also its boring to do same shit day in day out, this has brought some fun. 

Does not work in IE (from the url), but IE's dead anyway.

this one was funny:
 
data:text/html;base64, 

dare to copy/paste in your browser's address line? Or you shall decode it by hand first? Or you gonna write oneliner python/node/ruby coder/decoder to check it out first... LOL

I believe encoded  ones cannot be larger than 32K but then how much URL size a browser can tolerate?
If you make shortcut of the url on the desktop - is it working or not (with some people it works with some it does not etc etc.)

Lot of fun. made my day. Thanks again pycole for bringing the subject to spotlight.

> [pycole](#comment_32_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): No problem. :) I came across that a few weeks ago and suddenly it's relevant (how cool is that?).If you look thru the page It came from, I'm pretty sure there's another version that can actually save the created text file. A crazy enough person could integrate this with Zeroframe and make a WYSIWYG HTML editor--almost entirely written in HTML. The possibilities are crazy. It's so cool to see what HTML5 can do--even though it might not be finalized for years, and isn't even Turing complete.

Couple of years ago support for advanced browser features was just partially available with different level of support from the browsers also HTML5 was not fully covered either. With the development we got nice things that are working fast too (no flash, java applets and such stuff) Nowadays, it is a moment to re-asses these browser features and define bottom line browser support. So, I expect there will be more use of what is already a standard, in a new, creative ways. Zero net uses very nice implementation of sqlite db in JS. Combined with browsers local storage some interesting apps can be developed. By going down this line I found something called garlic,js - very interesting library.

On the other side, I liked desktop gitbook editor, although after some use of it, I find it not too friendly, but nothing that cannot be fixed really (and I hope it will be fixed). Editing in essence it good, in the middle pane you write markdown, on the right pane you see how text looks like in automatically refreshed preview. There is hierarchy of pages in the book (this part could be better - it is a bit confusing when you have larger structure). Also markdown is cut-down wiki so page linking is somewhat rudimentary (+ issues with the 'export' functions)

This method with local storage can only help to kill a bit of the functionality (does not need a lot of JS support) with what is already supported within the browser.

Yes, a lot of possibilities open from here.

ps. there is http://a5.gg but it has a small bug (again, it can be fixed). Some of the scripts work better. But I do not see a lot of discussion around the net for this subject, this means to me subject is not popular. (Yet :) I guess when someone makes something cool with it, it will suddenly get interesting.)

That worries me more. His deed is going on and developing. And only he's getting blamed for bad code.

There's unspoken genocide that goes on every day below news lines, of the kind that nobody gives a piece of shit, because we all believe we overpopulated this world. It will take much more than than recent ebola or refugee crisis to wake up. I am estimating killing a billion or two may cause appropriate wake up call and swing of focus. It is bound to happen sooner or later.

Until then. see ya, as there is nothing as good or educational as first hand experience. One realizes how deep shithole is, only when he gets to the bottom of it. We are all unconsciously sinking towards that bottom thru current self-obsessed world and consequently we are failing to notice that slow ride. So, see ya at the bottom, or maybe not ;)

5_1LRrd96P7FiTcsyNXVzPM5jtpQoH1B4gYf.body:
> [ekaterina](#comment_124_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): If ZeroNet is to actually replace the internet / become a serious alternative

This is a bit too ambitious to expect. For two reasons:

1. Internet is much more than web only (and there is long living misconception that web=internet, which of course it isn't, whereby web is very likely most used\*) - even that (most used) would be questionable if you look from some perspective - e.g. data transfer - web would be much lower on the scale of how much data has been transferred.

2. Zero net would not most likely replace normal web but something like ZeroNet will eventually (together with IPFS) become a new breed of internet services - based on hashes. I can envision from here a new uri schemes and fitting this new concept in the existing ones (as much as this would be heretical view of current ZeroNet user desires) - (and we will see reinventing the wheel in re-creating all services that have been created to clearnet to serve this new breed of 'hashed' services - this trend can already be spotted with existing development).

I find both ZeroNet and IPFS (and to some degree Freenet) having same essential concept but in spite that Freenet is around for a decade or so, humanity still did not figure that this approach deserves proper internet protocol (and perhaps supra (or integration) concept). I find that this realization will eventually happen in the time - usually such things happen when someone gets so bored doing the same thing again and again on information inter-exchange so one develops some convenient approach that people would eventually like.

I am even fond of the idea that this 'protocol' goes as down as extension of IP protocol (skipping OSI layer down) or up OSI layer becoming something like 'super-web'?!? (it shall then encompass normal http too to be complete like dynamic sites encompass static content). Current implementation of ZeroNet is struggling to fit into existing http - it lacks services that the 'browser' recognizes as native. So 'browser' will also need to change.

We will need this new breed of services very soon - as soon as IoT kicks in on larger scale - questions will be asked on how to automate tedious configuration and integration tasks, and of course you cannot setup web server for every small item that knows to communicate on the internet. (much like when DHCP appeared - yes in the dawn of internet IP addresses have been setup manually - today very few people setup IP numbers manually, most people on the internet actually never learned that there is some thing called IP number :) )

ZeroNet implementation currently uses browser as front end (presentation only) and instead of going directly down on dns, and ip sockets, and http protocol actually it 'outsources' exchange processing down to web server and p2p as execution/transport layer - good for experimenting but too complicated to non-technological user. In essence ZeroNet looks like that becomes in OSI layer one step up but it actually fits in between presentation and transportation layers. Browser will NEED to change to accommodate this problem and only way becomes to develop the protocol.

So, how you will feel if I tell you following:

I would like to have one server with plugins that cover freenet, zeronet, ipfs and perhaps dozen of other 'like' services in ONE functional system? I would like to choose which plugins to activate and how they shall be configured and have a several programming languages supporting the concept ... (what a wish huh - but this will eventually come - think of it today)
